utterances.sentences: Also, Larry Kudlow is considering this, he told me he was listening too in the car on the radio.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Larry Kudlow, perhaps the next national economic advisor for the president.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: CHAFFETZ

utterances.speaker: PERINO

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Are violent video games partly to blame for school shootings in America? President Trump is concerned about it. But gaming execs pushed back on the suggestion today at the White House. That's next.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: President Trump holding another meeting at the White House today in the wake of the Parkland school massacre. This time exploring whether violent video games are in any way linked to gun tragedies, something that he alluded to last week. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb16', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb16', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: The video games, the movies, the internet stuff is so violent. It's so incredible. I see it. I get to see things that you'd be amazed at. I have a very young son. I look at some of the things he's watching. And I say, how is that possible? And this is what kids are watching.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Well, the president met earlier with representatives of the industry and many rejected the idea that games lead to gun violence, noting that the same games are played in other countries that don't have these kinds of mass shootings. We'll go to little blueberry spice over here, who is our expert on this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, thank you for that. I am blueberry spice. All right. What complicates -- OK. There are some disturbing issues about this idea on both sides. If you read Dave Grossman book it's called, Assassination Generation. The reason why our troops improved their shooting skills so much from World War I to now is advancement in target practice. They move to fix targets to moving targets. And now, if you look at video games, they're similar to what you might do in simulation, learning how to shoot in modern-day warfare. So, Grossman points out that when you look at lot of these spectacles, these mass shootings, there are a lot more head shots because kids are just better at it. But, the data won't help you. New academic study shows as video games have become more and more popular, U.S. school shootings are down and they're safer than ever. Northeastern University, it was James Alan Fox, he's a professor of criminology, four times as many children were killed in schools in the 90's than they are now. Over 55 million school kids, an average of ten students a year that have been killed over 25 years. So you can do the math. It's compared to other things, it's very small. So as video games go up, it seems that this is on the decline. The only differences what we're seeing are spectacles and we have to admit that, that the numbers out of Chicago, obviously, people are getting killed in far greater numbers, but these spectacles grab our attention. But I don't think -- I think we're all trying to look for the magic villain.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So the left will say the NRA, and then the right will say I've talk about video games a lot, and I've talked about movies. And I do believe we have devalued the human currency in our pop culture. But I don't know if that translates by the numbers into deaths. I don't think you can make that leap, Though I understand the urgency to blame that when you see this stuff and you think all these kids do all day is try to kill each other. You know, it's got -- it has to have some kind of correlation. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb17', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb17', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But don't you think this is all about Trump trying to get away from conversations about gun control? I think that's the entirety of this whole thing. And here's the key for me. I think that you have the video industry, as Kimberly said in the introduction of this segment, saying, hey, we distribute around the globe. There is no other country where you see these mass shootings. Even as you say Greg, there's been a decrease. We have more mass shootings in any country in the world, and we don't have a specific limit in terms of who gets our violent video games.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Let me finish.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Major city where there is.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Let me finish.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: . we're one of the safest countries in the world. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: President Obama, even as a Democrat, thought there might be a link to the video games. He too was interested in this. But I think we've been through these arguments as a nation. On pornography, does pornography change the way, especially, men relate to women? How about on hard-core rap? I remember being in the midst of that argument and thinking, boy, this is terrible for our teenagers to be hearing about the N-word, misogyny, I've been in jail, I shot more people than you. We lose these arguments every time.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Fascinating.

utterances.speaker: CHAFFETZ
utterances.sentences: I think a lot of these come down to the breakdown of the family. I don't think it's necessarily the video games or the movies that come first. But there are a small subset of kids that can't distinguish right from wrong. And if you put them 15 hours in front of a scenario where they're killing people all day and they can't establish right from wrong, then they start to act on them. Remember the killing -- the mass killing - - I think it was Aurora, Colorado, in 2012, the summer, you know, at a Batman movie. This kid -- I mean, he was so mentally unstable. But I think a lot of it comes down to the breakdown of the family.

utterances.speaker: CHAFFETZ
utterances.sentences: But it's unfair to say that Donald Trump is avoiding a discussion. Donald Trump is going to get a lot of credit for having an open dialogue in the White House about a variety of subjects that are very difficult, and doing it in the light of day with all of the cameras going.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yeah. But one minute you think, oh, he's going to do something about guns. Then the NRA comes back says, oh, no, he's not doing it. He's no chain. I mean, all it is is a dog and pony show.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: All right. We have some breaking news real quick that I want to get to our viewers. The president of the United States has just made an announcement that South Korea is going to make a major announcement this evening at 7:00 PM Eastern. We'll bring it to you here at the Fox News Channel. Probably on Martha MacCallum's show. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I can tell you what it is now. I'm actually leaving The Five to go become the president of South Korea.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So there you go. So don't worry about 7:00.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Way to blow it for us, Greg. Let's go to our real individual - - congressman, what do you make of this in terms of what the major announcement might be regarding South Korea?

utterances.speaker: CHAFFETZ
utterances.sentences: I don't know. I wish I knew. I look over at Greg and all I can see is the Willy Wonka when the kid eats all those blueberries and then starts floating up to the top saw.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That is then my dream.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Exactly. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CHAFFETZ
utterances.sentences: I'm a little distracted.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, trying to think of the time difference with South Korea.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Fourteen hours?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So if it's 7:00 PM here, that must mean it's 5:00 AM there or something?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right, 14 hours.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You're going to make an announcement, then it's probably what they would consider to be good news. I really doubt it's going to be that Kim Jong-un has agreed to denuclearizing, then there's going to be sunshine and light and unicorns hopping around the Korean peninsula. But it's significant enough for the president to make an announcement that he wants us all to watch.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Right. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: . South Korea is going to say at 7:00, I guess we better tune in.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: OK. Well, it's been characterized as a major announcement, so obviously it's going to be something of significance. And they're letting us know ahead of time, about an hour and half prior to the announcement, so we'll keep an eye on that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I think South Korea has taken the lead on this. They're the ones setting up this whole thing. And I think what you're likely to hear is that South Korea says the United States would be a full party to these negotiations.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think this is -- again, when you look at the news of the week with North Korea talking -- mentioning denuclearization, even if you don't like Trump, you've got to hand it to him on this. This strategy has been working. To be the unstable -- I know you're moaning, but to be unpredictable.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It's not about Trump. Everything is about Trump with you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What I'm trying to say is this is the first time we have been the unpredictable member of the party, the person that you have to worry about, and this is the result you're getting. I think it's hopeful.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yeah. I mean, obviously, I think it's going to be a positive announcement. The president is already telegraphing it, going to be a major announcement. Has to be something that's significant regarding what's going on with North Korea, South Korea, and hopefully there's going to be some stewardship. Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I was just thinking, who I'm going to get to be on The Daily Briefing tomorrow to talk about North Korea.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Me.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So producers, if you're watching, can you get me some Dennis Wilder on the phone please.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Listen.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Dennis Wilder, I'll take either one of them.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: This one is always closing. She's already booking a show for tomorrow. All right, ahead, a story that hasn't gotten much coverage because nothing happened. Thanks to law enforcement who did something after concerned American said something right back.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: The mass murder in Broward County was a huge story. But what about another chilling event where nothing nearly as bad happened but could have? Saint George, Utah, homemade explosive was found in a backpack. On Monday, a student saw the backpack in a common area at Pine View High, which looked to be smoking. The police have the student who notified faculty and the school officer prevented an explosion that would have caused mass casualties. Police got to the suspect's home, found the bomb making materials as well as info suggesting he'd been researching ISIS. Last month, the suspect may have also replaced the American flag at a different high school with an ISIS one and painted part of an ISIS-inspired threat on one wall. So why don't you hear about this story? Well, it's obvious. First, the bomb didn't go off. That's how news works. We never report when the plane lands safely. And of course, the weapon was not a gun but a bomb. Anyway, we should be grateful that no one got hurt, but don't be relieved because the only reason why no one got hurt is that they got lucky. That backpack smoked and a kid saw it. I return to the solution: hardening soft targets. Surveillance cameras should have caught the kid painting the wall or replacing the flag. Metal detectors could do a lot to reduce all threats. But right now all we have to rely on our eyeballs and chance. We can do better. So Dana, this story was on the front page of USA Today.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Seven hundred and fifty six copycat threats since the Parkland mass murder. And there's been -- I mean, I've always say this is why -- I think it's good that we play down the reporting of this because the attention builds copycats.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And it's not just for shootings, this happens also with other types of crimes as we know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: In this one, the case like the raising of the ISIS flag, when you talk about a red flag.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Like, OK, there's a problem here.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's a black flag.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: We need to find him.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I'm going to offer another solution --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- in terms of hardening the targets. You're going to think I'm a little ridiculous but hear me out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And I think that if you -- you could arm teachers if you want. Localities if that's what you decide to do. You could have police officers there. I also think dogs make a big difference. They can -- bomb-sniffing dogs, ammunition-sniffing dogs.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's always dogs with you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: They also have -- they're a great deterrent.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: They really are for your home security or for schools. And it's actually a pretty affordable one. You can't just have them there by themselves. They have to have a handler, of course.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That means that you actually have --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I see a second business for you. After -- after you -- I see a second business.

utterances.speaker: KIMBERLY GUILFOYLE, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: What is it?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: If you think about all these dogs that are coming back from wartime.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK? They've got a couple more years in them.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's true. That's true.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: We could use them.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know the area, too.

utterances.speaker: JASON CHAFFETZ, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Yes. Look, this is southwestern Utah. And you worry because law enforcement has got to take this very seriously. But I think you're both right. The Pentagon sent more than $20 billion to try to figure out how to find improvised explosive devices and weapons. And after this, their No. 1 conclusion, the best way to find this: dogs.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CHAFFETZ
utterances.sentences: It's not some technology. It's not some -- it's dogs is the single best way to do it. But we do have -- we do have to harden some of these soft targets. And law enforcement has got to have the people's back when they actually want to go prosecute these people. Even though the kid may be 17 years old, we've got to believe them --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CHAFFETZ
utterances.sentences: -- and prosecute.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And there's got to be a way to tag them civilly. If they're law- abiding -- if this kid is deranged but he hasn't broken the law, we need a database. So you know, when you see -- I don't know how this guy, Juan, was able to replace a flag on a school and not get caught. I mean --

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: I think most people would think the problem is the guy is crazy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Right? So they would think -- I mean, I think they would react less to which flag, and they think "What flag is that anyway? What is the kid doing?" But nobody apparently asked the question.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It would be very different if it was a "Don't Tread on Me" flag, versus an ISIS flag.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, I think the whole idea, to respond to what Greg is saying, is that if the kid changed the flag -- and I think if people -- if you're specifically saying is this an Islamic terror connection? And oftentimes with shootings, that's the first time we looked at. I think the recent reports when it came to the Parkland -- oh, he's got some -- and of course, it's not true. It's just that he's deranged. And I think that's the bigger area for me. I don't mind having some precautions in place, but I think we have to discuss kids who are mentally ill, coming back to your family breakdown stuff, no father, no direction. And second, I think we've got to talk about guns and that these people shouldn't have access to guns.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. That gun -- that was a bomb. But anyway, Kimberly, finish.

utterances.speaker: KIMBERLY GUILFOYLE, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: It goes to show you where somebody has this kind of intention, they're going to do whatever it takes to get some kind of weapon to effectuate the outcome that they are desiring, whether it's somebody making, like the Tsarnaev brothers with the pressure cookers, or someone downloading some of these videos that are available to people to see. Which, you know, is very troubling, in and of itself. They're going to find a way to do it. But I am a very big proponent of having dogs and utilizing them. I've seen them be very effective with law enforcement. When I worked as a prosecutor and also in schools that I have taught in as an educator, as well. So, you know, I think it's a fantastic idea, and I also am familiar with some organizations that do this. And why not? Why wouldn't we? You know, we use them in the military. We use them in the armed forces, because they are effective.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: At the train stations, bus stations.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. So why not protect our schools?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. I just worry that so far we're relying so much on luck and chance.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. More to come in just a moment.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: President Trump moving ahead with sweeping new tariffs on steel and aluminum today, moves sharply at odds with many in his own party.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP (R), PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: The strong steel and aluminum industry are vital to our national security. Absolutely vital. Steel is steel. You don't have steel, you don't have a country. The American steel and aluminum industry has been ravaged by aggressive foreign trade practices. It's really an assault on our country. It's been an assault. The actions we're taking today are not a matter of choice. They're a matter of necessity for our security.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The proclamations exclude Canada and Mexico, possibly other nations, as well, down the road. Now some Republicans like Ben Sasse argue the tariffs will kill American jobs and hurt our economy. Do you agree, congressman?

utterances.speaker: CHAFFETZ
utterances.sentences: Look, I think we need to give the president a lot of latitude on this one. The status quo is not necessarily working for us. The president campaigned for it. He said exactly what he's going to do. The president is always negotiating, always putting other people back on their heels. And I think he should be given some latitude to see how this works out and let him do what he said he was going to do.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Before you stop, what about the divide within the party?

utterances.speaker: CHAFFETZ
utterances.sentences: I think it's healthy to have a debate. I mean, this came up pretty quickly, although he'd been campaigning for it for a year. There is a vibrant debate. Where I really think there's going to be a tough thing is for the Democrats. Because what do they have to campaign for? They've got Donald Trump, who's pulling up every blue-collar Democrat, and they're going for Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK. Kimberly, the Koch Brothers even are saying they don't agree with this, because they say free trade is essential to American prosperity. This will cost us jobs. They point back --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- to Bush tariffs, Obama tariffs that didn't work. And of course, Smoot-Hawley at the start of the Great Depression.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes, and there's 100 congressional leaders that have also requested that the president trim the tariffs back and what he's going to do. I think we've got to follow what he's -- he's met with his economic advisors. Let's give him a chance and see how this works out. Hopefully, it will stimulate our economy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, the president has had a steely resolve on this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Ooh.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's one of the things that a lot of conservatives on the protectionist front -- on the protectionist issue. I just can't get my head around it. Grover Norquist tweeted, like, four times right in a row "A tariff is a tax. A tariff is a tax. A tariff" -- and it's just because economic theory always gets you back to the same point, which is that -- I want American businesses to be able to compete, and I want American workers to be able to have great jobs, and I want American consumers to be able to afford good products that they want to buy. And I think that if we want to compete fairly, that we win 85 percent of the cases that we take to the World Trade Organization and that there's just a better way to go about this.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And Greg, do you worry about a full global trade war at this point?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Not really. I mean, he's exempting Canada and Mexico. So -- so that makes Trump half a globalist. Or a bi-globalist. Or a continentalist. Or North American nationalist? I'm not sure. But it's good news, because it seems that he's flexible. The bigger story is when you look at Mike Pence, OK? What happens when you're an ideologue who's trafficked in the team sport of left versus right and now you're walking away from those beliefs, because some of those beliefs were pure free trade? And it creates a new war of opposition. So now we have new labels. We have "You're a globalist, and I'm a nationalist." And so instead of calling you a RINO, I'm going to call you a globalist, which is every bit as silly as every other team sport ideology. And I think that it's much more complicated than that. But I'm glad to see that he's exempting Canada and Mexico. That means, you know, he's not -- he's our kind of globalist.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- now.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right. So there's some breaking news out of the White House, as we told you earlier on the Koreas. Chief White House correspondent John Roberts joins us now with details -- John.

utterances.speaker: JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Hey, Juan. Good afternoon to you. We have a first here at the White House. After 413 days, President Trump stuck his nose and his toes, that's about all, into the briefing room. He opened the door between the lower press office and the briefing to say that there was going to be a major announcement from South Korea at about 7 p.m. tonight. The topic will be North Korea. The South Korean national security advisor has been at the White House all day with his staff, meeting with H.R. McMaster, our national security advisor, to talk about what looks like a bit of a breakthrough here, with Kim Jong-un agreeing that he will come to Panmunjom border crossing between North and South Korea and go to what's called the Peace House, which is actually on the South Korean side of the border, for the very first talks that he has ever had with Moon Jae-in, who is the South Korean president. In fact, it will mark the first time since the Korean War that a North Korean leader has actually been on South Korean soil. All of this, the White House hopes, would be leading toward direct talks between the United States and North Korea about getting rid of its nuclear weapons program. The president has said that he would only talk to North Korea if it was about denuclearizing the Korean Peninsula, and it looks like we may be getting closer to that point. We don't know what the substance of the announcement will be here, but it will be on North Korea and it will be coming from South Korea, Juan, in the Brady Briefing Room at about 7 p.m. So keep watching for that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much, John. Did you have any thoughts on this, Congressman?

utterances.speaker: CHAFFETZ
utterances.sentences: Well, I believe Kim Jong-un -- I don't believe has ever met with another world leader.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CHAFFETZ
utterances.sentences: So if that's happening with the new President Moon -- I've actually been in that Peace House. It will be a very significant moment. And I do think you have to give some credence to what Donald Trump has been doing. The rhetoric, combined with the military might, it's been having an effect. And I hope this is as positive as it sounds.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The other thing is, I think it's really significant. I didn't realize that the South Korean national security advisor was -- I think I had read about that this morning. But when we talked about it when the news first broke that there was going to be this statement, I thought it was coming from South Korea. But it's actually, at the end of today And one of the things the North Koreans had tried to do was to drive a wedge between the United States and South Korea. And it appears that the United States and South Korea have remained strong enough in their alliance and then forcing Kim Jong-un to come to them. It's a pretty good development.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes. I think this is -- it's very auspicious. I'm looking forward to the announcement in detail. I think this is a tremendous forward progression development here that really will help in terms of an international, you know, peace. And this is something that everybody should be happy about, and I think in full measure, you know, credence to President Trump.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And now John Bolton.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Gangnam style.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It will be fun.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Technology certainly makes our lives more convenient. But are these gadgets like Alexa getting a little creepy? Next.

utterances.speaker: CHAFFETZ
utterances.sentences: Alexa, please stop laughing.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Alexa, play the last sound.

utterances.speaker: ROBOTIC VOICE
utterances.sentences: (LAUGHING)

utterances.speaker: CHAFFETZ
utterances.sentences: It's kind of creepy. If you're one of the users who have been hearing haunting cackles like that from your device, fear not. Amazon says it's performing an exorcism. The company says it's working to fix the unprompted laughs coming out of some of its virtual assistants. Meanwhile, Movie Pass just fixed a feature from its app that let the company track customers after widespread backlash. Is technology generally becoming too creepy? I happen to think the answer is yes. But Kimberly, what do you think?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think it is kind of creepy. That's why I always tell my little -- leave Alexa in his room. I don't know. But he loves her. He travels with her and everything. But you do have to be careful, because you notice all the tracking devices, all those apps that you download, they all say allow them to access them, or allow them to track you. Why do they need to be tracking you? Because they are just sucking all the information for marketing purposes about your life. It is very Big Brother-ish. And if you're kind of creepy like Greg, you should be concerned.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Greg's the little brother.

utterances.speaker: CHAFFETZ
utterances.sentences: Greg, is it creeping you out?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, OK, let's explain the creepy laugh. No. 1, Amazon could actually have mined the consciousness of their workers, downloaded them into each device, and those laughs are actually cries for help. There are people trapped inside those devices. You've got to get them out. But here's the irony, OK? Google, like people have no problem --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Them, as well.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: People have no problem with companies like Google taking your information and making billions of dollars off your information. However, Google employees are upset that Google is working with the military to help make their drones more effective. So they want your info, but they don't want to help out those who keep us free enough so they can steal your info. That bothers me.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, not only that, but the FBI is desperate to try to get the tech companies to help them --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- so that they can, in real time, help protect people. And that is going to come to a head pretty soon. That said, I actually kind of like the convenience of it sometimes. Although I was creeped out today. This happened this morning. I walked by a shoe shop in Columbus Circle. And I was like, "Oh, those are cute." So I went online, as one does, and I checked the price. I was like, "God, those are so extensive." So I put it away. By the time I got off the subway, I got an email from them saying, "We noticed you were checking us out." Don't do that to me.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: No, that's what they do.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Dobbs does that to me all the time.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: You wish.

utterances.speaker: CHAFFETZ
utterances.sentences: Juan, you've got kids, grandkids. Do you worry about them carrying these smart phones and all these devices that will track your -- your loved ones?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, it's troublesome to me in that they get so much information about people's habits and -- it's not that I think there's going to be a threat to them, although I guess it's possible. I haven't seen that realized yet. What bothers me is the sense of lack of privacy. I think that there should be an assumption -- and I think the courts would side with me on this -- that you have a right to the expectation of some privacy. So for example, on the Moviefone deal, Greg and I were talking about it. It's a great deal. You get to watch a movie a day, set prices much cheaper. But then they track you even when you leave the movie theater. You know, or like Dana, when I walk around around there's some -- I think it's Foursquare will tell me, "Hey, you're in midtown Manhattan. Do you want to eat here?" And I think, "Get away for me."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's me.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Because Juan, you have to turn it off on your phone.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: We'll turn it off for you. We'll show you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Thank you, love.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I kind of like being bothered.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's your friend?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Because he's crying out for attention. So I mean, if he gets it from an app, he'll take it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't like making decisions. Make them for me. That's what I say.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: But you make the same decisions in a repetitive fashion.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Because of your OCD nature.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: You want the salt and pepper, pork chop. Same thing. Your little structure.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Don't knock the salt and pepper pork chops. They're amazing.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: -- with the beef jerky.

utterances.speaker: CHAFFETZ
utterances.sentences: All right. "One More Thing" is coming up next. Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Time now for "One More Thing." With happy birthday eve, Kimberly Guilfoyle.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much, my little blueberry twin. Cute. Little smurfer over there, Greg. All right. Today, Greg and I have a joint "One More Thing," and we would like to celebrate International Women's Day. And Greg and I have been talking about this for a long time. We think it's very important. March is Women's History Month here in the United States of America, and people around the world are celebrating this together.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Ack! Started by communists!

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Here are pictures in the four square boxes. And the day is aimed at inspiring women everywhere --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Started by communists!

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: -- and celebrating their achievements. You're going to get lit up from the Internet. I can't wait. It's actually an official holiday, Greg, in 15 countries, including China, Vietnam, and the Ukraine --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What do they have in common?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Government offices, schools and stores are closed. Oh, boy, you're going to get an avalanche. I can't wait. And even McDonald's, a big franchise here --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What's McDonald's favorite color? Red.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: OK, but then yellow. They will turn the archers upside down for "W's" in a number of their locations to be able to support women. So I think this is fantastic, and you should be very much celebrating this, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, I'll celebrate it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK. Greg's going to love this one, too. Take a look at this Corgi. This is Pax of Houston, Texas. Now he got groomed, and his owner put this photo up. And can you believe Americans responders said -- like, started fat shaming this dog and it all became this whole thing about how much does this dog weigh? And then they just kept going back and forth, and back and forth. America, stop it. Do not fat shame dogs.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's not like he knows.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I know. Well, the owner was upset.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, don't feed the dog so much, owner.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The dog's not fat. The dog is right in range. His BMI is fantastic. Of course, Greg --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't know. I don't know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You're next.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Struggling.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: To my own.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.sentences: Greg's Penguin Selfie News

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: "Greg's Penguin Selfie News." All right. This is really interesting. Two emperor penguins -- they do exist -- in the Antarctica, they captured a short video of themselves -- take a picture of this.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: This is amazing. They found a camera left on the ice by humans. This reminds me of that time I woke up nude at the Central Park Zoo. And it was just -- they --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: And Dobbs had to come pick you up?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes, yes. He was so mad.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes, he was so mad.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But I got to write in his Jaguar, so it was cool. Anyway, they're actually re-adapting the scene from "Goodfellas," the trunk scene, you know? When they put the guy in the trunk, just seeing if he's still alive. I don't know. Anyway, kind of adorable.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I like them, too. Pretty cute. Pretty cute. Juan.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: The best "One More Thing" you're going to see.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: On International Women's Day.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Who killed JFK? What happened at Area 51? And where is Amelia Earhart's remains? Where can they be found? Well, one of these mysteries now solved. A new scientific study of bones concludes that Earhart died on a coral island in the Pacific. She was attempting to fly around the world, 1937, when her plane disappeared. The latest theory is based on a review of bones. The professor who did the study says there's now more than a 99 percent similarity to her bones, more than anyone else, 99 percent of the rest of the population.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wow. That's pretty interesting. That is a mystery we didn't think would be solved.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Fascinating, isn't it? Science and technology.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And on Women's Day.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes. Also, if you're thinking to get someone --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: A woman spends --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Excuse me, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- two years in prison for not wearing a hijab, we should talk about that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Was the island a communist? OK.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: We can talk about that, too.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Jason Chaffetz.

utterances.speaker: CHAFFETZ
utterances.sentences: Big, big news in the Chaffetz family, because my wife Julie and I actually became grandparents.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I saw the picture. So cute.

utterances.speaker: CHAFFETZ
utterances.sentences: even our grandkids come prebaked with heads of hair. and she's a beautiful girl. Our daughter and son-in-law, it's just a true miracle. I feel like I'm 33 years old, but I'm a little bit older than that. I have a grandchild at this point. Screaming her -- screaming her lungs out.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Congratulations. God bless.

utterances.speaker: CHAFFETZ
utterances.sentences: I'm very proud of my daughter and son-in-law.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And may there be many, many more in your future.

utterances.speaker: CHAFFETZ
utterances.sentences: I hope so.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. Set your DVRs. Never miss an episode of "The Five," because it's pretty fabulous. "Special Report" is next.
